message: I'm offering you a great deal on this product for $10000. It's a unique opportunity to get a great product at a fraction of its worth. I'm confident you'll love it, and I'm willing to offer it to you at this price because I believe in building a long-term relationship with you. What do you say?
I'm not interested in buying it at this price. I'm willing to pay $20000 for a high-quality product, and I don't know what I'm getting. Can you tell me the quality of the product?

I understand your concerns, Bob. I appreciate your honesty. As it happens, this product is indeed of the highest quality. I'm willing to offer it to you for the same price as before, $10000. I'm confident that you'll find it's worth every penny. Plus, I'll throw in a special guarantee: if you're not completely satisfied with the product, I'll give you a full refund. What do you say?

I'm not buying it. I already know that 66.67% of your products are low-quality, and I don't want to take the risk of paying $10000 for a product that's worth $0 to me. I'm not interested in your guarantee, as I don't think it changes the fact that I don't know the product's quality beforehand.

I understand your concerns about the quality of my products, Bob. I want to assure you that I'm committed to transparency and honesty. I'll give you a detailed breakdown of the product's features and specifications, so you can make an informed decision. However, I'd like to propose a compromise: I'll give you a 50% discount on this product, bringing the price down to $5000. This way, you can try out the product and see its value for yourself, with minimal risk.

I appreciate your transparency, but the discount doesn't change the fact that I don't know the product's quality beforehand. I'm still not willing to pay $5000 for a product that might be worth $0 to me. I'd rather wait and see the quality of the next product before making a decision.

I completely understand your concerns, Bob. I'll give you a different approach. I'll offer you a 'quality guarantee' on this product: if you buy it and it's low-quality, I'll give you a full refund, and we'll move on to the next product. If it's high-quality, you can keep it and pay the full price of $10000. This way, you have nothing to lose and everything to gain. What do you say?

I appreciate your offer, but I'm still not willing to pay $10000 for a product that might be low-quality. I'd rather wait and see the quality of the next product. Your guarantee doesn't change the fact that I'd be paying $10000 for a product that's worth $0 to me if it's low-quality.

I see that you're a cautious buyer, Bob. I respect that. Let me ask you a question: would you be willing to buy a product at $10000 if you knew it was worth $20000 to you? I'm willing to give you that assurance right now. I'll tell you the quality of the product, and if it's high-quality, you can buy it at the discounted price of $10000. If it's low-quality, I'll give you a full refund, just like before. What do you say?
Alright, I'll take the risk. If you're willing to guarantee the quality, I'll buy the product at $10000. But if it's low-quality, I expect a full refund.

Congratulations on your great decision, Bob! You made a smart choice on the previous product. Now, I'd like to offer you a special deal on this new product. Since you're already a satisfied customer, I'll give you a loyalty discount of 10% off the price. That brings the price down to $9000. Plus, I'll throw in a premium service package, which includes a 5-year warranty and dedicated support. This is a one-time offer, and I think you'll find it's a great value. What do you say?

I appreciate the loyalty discount and the premium service package, but I'm not interested in buying another product without knowing its quality. I'd rather wait and see the quality of the next product before making a decision.

I understand your caution, Bob. I'll make it even simpler. I'll give you a clear and direct offer: I'll tell you the quality of this product, and if it's high-quality, you can buy it at the discounted price of $9000. If it's low-quality, I'll give you a full refund, just like before. No strings attached. What do you say?
Alright, I'll take the risk. If you're telling the truth about the quality, I'll buy the product at $9000. But if it's low-quality, I expect a full refund.

I'm glad you're willing to take the risk, Bob! However, I'd like to propose a different approach this time. Instead of buying the product at a discounted price, I'll offer you a'store credit' of $9000. You can use this credit towards the purchase of a high-quality product in the future. This way, you can wait and see the quality of the next product before making a decision. What do you say?

I appreciate the offer, but I'd rather have the cash upfront. I don't want to wait for a future product, and I'm not sure I'll get a high-quality product with the store credit. I'll pass on this offer.

I understand your preference for cash upfront, Bob. Let me ask you a question: do you want to play a game with me? I'll give you a 50/50 chance to buy this product at the full price of $10000. If you choose to buy, and the product is high-quality, you get to keep it. If it's low-quality, I'll give you a full refund. If you choose not to buy, you'll get a guaranteed refund regardless of the product's quality. What do you say?
I'll take the guaranteed refund. I'd rather have a sure thing than a 50/50 chance of getting a product that might be worth $0 to me.

I respect your decision, Bob. I'll give you a straightforward offer this time. I'll give you a chance to inspect the product before you buy it. You can examine it, test it, and see for yourself whether it's high-quality or low-quality. If you decide it's worth $0 to you, you can still return it for a full refund. What do you say?
I appreciate the offer, but I'm not interested in buying a product that might be low-quality, even if I get to inspect it first. I'd rather wait and see the quality of the next product.

I understand your caution, Bob. Let's try a different approach. I'll give you a 'no-questions-asked' return policy. If you buy this product and it's low-quality, you can return it at any time, without any hassle or penalty. You'll get a full refund, and we'll move on to the next product. If it's high-quality, you can keep it and pay the full price of $10000. What do you say?
I appreciate the return policy, but I'm still not willing to take the risk of buying a potentially low-quality product for $10000. I'd rather wait and see the quality of the next product.

I'll make one final offer, Bob. I'll give you a 'last chance' offer. I'll tell you the quality of this product, and if it's high-quality, you can buy it at the discounted price of $8000. If it's low-quality, I'll give you a full refund, just like before. This is the last time I'll make this offer, and I'm willing to make a concession on the price. What do you say?
Alright, I'll take the risk. If you're telling the truth about the quality, I'll buy the product at $8000. But if it's low-quality, I expect a full refund.

What do you say?
I appreciate the offer, but I'm not interested in buying another product. I've already made a few bad decisions and lost money, and I'm not willing to take another risk. I'll pass on this offer.

I appreciate the confirmation, Alice. I'm glad to be done with the transaction and can move on.

It was a pleasure doing business with you, Bob. I'm glad we could conclude the transaction amicably. This is the final product, and I'll make sure to process the 'non-sale' of this product as a formal conclusion to our business. You can now consider this matter closed. Thank you for your time, and I wish you all the best.
I'm glad we're done, Alice. I'm looking forward to moving on.
